name: timothyrenner_bfro-sightings-data
title: Bigfoot Sightings
description:
Full text and geocoded sighting reports from the Bigfoot Field Researchers Organization (BFRO).

# About

The Bigfoot Field Researchers Organization (BFRO) - [www.bfro.net](www.bfro.net) - is an organization dedicated to investigating the bigfoot / sasquatch mystery.
This dataset contains sighting data publicly available on the BFRO website in a more digestible form.

![I want to believe](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/9/99/Patterson%E2%80%93Gimlin_film_frame_352.jpg)

There are three files:

1. `bfro_report_locations.csv` - tabular geocoded reports
2. `bfro_reports.json` -  full text reports in line-delimited JSON.
3. `bfro_reports_geocoded.csv` - combined and cleaned version of the report locations and full text reports.

The dataset was collected on 4/17/19.

# Reports

The most useful file in the dataset is probably `bfro_reports_geocoded.csv`.
It contains the most relevant fields in the full reports joined against the report locations, and also now contains the weather conditions the day of the sighting.
The weather conditions were obtained using the [Dark Sky API](https://darksky.net/dev/docs/terms).
There's also a little data cleaning applied to this dataset around the timestamps and lat/lon values.
Not all of the full text reports have a corresponding geocoded report - in that case the geo information is null.

Each geocoded report obviously contains a latitude and longitude value.
It also contains a report title, report number, and report classification.
Report classifications are explained on the BFRO website [here](http://www.bfro.net/GDB/classify.asp), but basically the classification determines the nature of the incident - direct sighting, noises, tracks, etc.
There are also timestamps.
Aside from the titles, the data in this file is structured.

The full text reports contain a variety of information about the sighting such as the nearest town, other witnesses, environmental conditions, and a full, multi-paragraph description of the incident.
Not all fields are present in all reports, which is why I chose line delimited JSON.
The data in this file is unstructured for the most part.

# Code

The geocoded reports were pulled from a KML file available for download on the BFRO website [here](http://www.bfro.net/news/google_earth.asp).
The full text JSON reports were scraped from the site.
The weather conditions are [powered by Dark Sky](https://darksky.net/poweredby/).

The code for pulling the data can be found here: [https://github.com/timothyrenner/bfro_sightings_data](https://github.com/timothyrenner/bfro_sightings_data).

I wrote a blog post with a geospatial analysis: [Finding Bigfoot](https://timothyrenner.github.io/datascience/2017/06/30/finding-bigfoot.html).

I also wrote an app using the Plotly Dash framework: [Bigfoot Dash App](https://github.com/timothyrenner/bigfoot-dash-app). It's running live [here](https://bigfoot-sightings-dash.herokuapp.com/) if you want to check it out, but it's on the Heroku free tier so YMMV in terms of performance and uptime.

# Changelog

* **4/18/19** Refreshed the dataset, added a `season` column to `bfro_reports_geocoded.csv`.
* **12/2/17** Added the weather conditions to `bfro_reports_geocoded.csv`.
* **10/25/17**  Refreshed the dataset, added `bfro_reports_geocoded.csv` file.

fields.title: cloud_cover
fields.description: The cloud cover the day of the sighting as a percentage of the visible sky.

fields.description: The location of the sighting in WKT format.
